topband.label: Rebooter, not broken — stories from known faces

hero.title: Reset. Restart. Renew.
hero.subtitle: You've closed a chapter — maybe willingly, maybe not — and now you're staring at a blank screen called "next."

line.0: Do you feel relief and fear in equal measure?
line.1: Does this restart feel heavier than your first start?
line.2: Are you carrying lessons — or luggage — from the past?
line.3: Do you keep asking yourself 'can I really do this again?'
line.4: What if your next build could be lighter, faster, and truer?

2.name: J.K. Rowling
2.quote: "Rock bottom became the solid foundation on which I rebuilt my life."

3.name: Elon Musk
3.quote: "Failure is an option. If things aren't failing, you aren't innovating enough."

4.name: Maya Angelou
4.quote: "Try to be a rainbow in someone's cloud."

0.title: The Pause Before the Relaunch
0.line: You've shut down more than just the old system.
0.body: Whether it's a career change, ending a partnership, or stepping away from a dream, this is more than a break. It's the quiet between storms — where your next choice will define the next chapter.

bullet.0: You walked away from something that looked fine on the outside.
bullet.1: You're deliberately taking time before your next move.

0.nudge: List three non‑negotiables for your next chapter — and keep them in sight.
0.cta: Define your reboot before the world does it for you →

1.title: Carrying Lessons, Not Luggage
1.line: Your past is a library, not a prison.
1.body: Every ending leaves you with stories, scars, and strategies. The challenge is knowing which to keep and which to let go.

bullet.0: You find yourself replaying the same mistakes.
bullet.1: You hesitate to trust your own decisions.
bullet.2: You know what you don't want, but not yet what you do.

1.nudge: Write down one hard‑earned lesson — and one fear you can release with it.

2.title: Building the Next Version of You
2.line: This isn't a repeat — it's an upgrade.
2.body: The beauty of starting again is that you're not truly starting from scratch. You have frameworks, resilience, and the clarity that only comes from experience.

bullet.0: You're mixing old skills with new ideas.
bullet.1: You're designing your next life to fit who you are now.
bullet.2: You feel ready to take calculated risks.

2.nudge: Create a 'Version 2.0' vision board — with images, not just words.

1.h: Building the Next Version of You

2.cta: Build the reboot you've been dreaming of →

3.title: Thriving After the Reset
3.line: The reset isn't the end — it's the training ground.
3.body: Once you've found your footing, you can use your restart to build a life that's more aligned, resilient, and satisfying than before.

bullet.0: You want this time to truly stick.
bullet.1: You're mentoring others who are restarting.
bullet.2: You feel proud of how far you've come.

3.nudge: Share your reboot story with someone just starting theirs.
3.cta: Turn your restart into a legacy →

bridge.title: Every restart is a step forward, not backward.
bridge.body: Drishiq helps you see your restarts as growth opportunities, learn from past experiences, and build something stronger each time.

0.d: Chart where you've been and where you're going.

1.d: Keep the wisdom, drop the weight.

topband.label: Seeker, not lost — stories from known faces

hero.title: Seeking New Dimensions
hero.subtitle: You've read, explored, asked, and still the pieces don't fully fit. Here's a space to pause the chase and listen inward.

line.0: Do you feel you're always 'on the verge' of finding your answer?
line.1: Have you explored many paths but settled on none?
line.2: Do you get pulled toward the next possibility before finishing the last?
line.3: Are you searching more for relief than direction?
line.4: What if the answer wasn't 'out there' but already inside?

1.name: Oprah Winfrey
1.quote: "The biggest adventure you can take is to live the life of your dreams."

2.name: David Attenborough
2.quote: "An understanding of the natural world is a source of curiosity and fulfilment."

3.name: J.K. Rowling
3.quote: "It is impossible to live without failing at something..."

4.name: Elon Musk
4.quote: "Ordinary people can choose to be extraordinary."

0.title: The Thrill and the Exhaustion
0.line: Seeking can be a gift, but also a loop.
0.body: You love the chase — the spark of a new idea, the pull of a fresh path. But with each turn, the destination shifts. It's exhilarating… and draining.

bullet.0: You often start many things but finish few.
bullet.1: You feel restless when you're not pursuing something.
bullet.2: You've lost count of the number of 'next big things' you've tried.

0.nudge: List your last five pursuits. Mark which ones you truly want to finish — and why.

1.title: The Fear of Missing the Right Path
1.body: Sometimes you chase because you're afraid the 'right thing' might pass you by. But in trying everything, you rarely stay long enough to grow roots.

bullet.0: You worry you'll regret not trying something.
bullet.2: You look for signs you're 'meant' to do something.

1.nudge: Ask yourself: 'What am I afraid will happen if I choose one path?'

2.title: Searching to Avoid Sitting Still
2.line: Stillness can feel scarier than confusion.
2.body: For some seekers, movement is a way to avoid confronting uncertainty or pain. It's easier to run toward something than sit with what is.

bullet.0: You fill your calendar to avoid reflection.
bullet.1: You chase ideas when you're anxious.
bullet.2: You feel 'empty' when there's nothing new to aim for.

2.nudge: Spend 15 minutes today in complete stillness — no screens, no plans. Notice what surfaces.

3.title: Finding While Seeking
3.line: The journey can be the answer.
3.body: Not all seeking is about arriving. Some is about becoming. But to become, you have to let some discoveries land and shape you before moving on.

bullet.0: You have wisdom but don't apply it.
bullet.1: You rush past small wins to the next chase.
bullet.2: You want your search to feel more fulfilling.

3.nudge: Name one lesson from your last pursuit and decide how to live it for the next month.

bridge.title: The answer may not be where you're looking.
bridge.body: Drishiq helps seekers like you turn restless motion into grounded direction. Your questions matter — and so does your ability to rest in the answers you already hold.

0.d: Lay out your pursuits and see patterns.

1.d: Filter ideas through what matters most.

2.d: Stay with a choice long enough to grow from it.

3.d: Notice the progress you've already made.
